comments.commentBody:
Yes, all he needs is one of these:
http://pilates.about.com/od/technique/ss/human-spine-anatomy_3.htm

Obama clearly and repeatedly came out against George W. Bush's invasion of Iraq. Now that he is president, he has had to carefully wind down W's mess.

Obama will still, in any case, win in a competition with any of the current Republican candidates.

Message for Obama:

If you had the guts to embrace Ron Paul's anti-war anti-WS stance, you would win with a landslide.

Yes, Santorum is indeed the big government, status quo, conservative that can challenge Romney, especially with Gingrich going on the offensive to equate him with Obama and support his close friend Rick.

Very good comment. I'm afraid that all the chickens let loose by Citizens United are coming home to roost. What happened to Gingrich (not that I have any sympathy for him considering his sad history) is just a preview of what will happen to Obama once the Republican media dogs are unleashed, flush with corporate cash with no disclosed sources, being spent against Obama in unprecedented levels. I must admit I do wonder, after the birthers and others that have gotten more than their fifteen minutes of fame, what other innuendo could be spread about Obama, but since those that wish to "Machiavelli" Obama do not have to disclose names or the source of their funding anymore, I'm sure the untruths will be flying fast and furious. Somehow, I doubt that the framers of our Constitution had this in mind when they wrote it; that money = free speech and that free speech = the free-flowing well of untruths and innuendo in a political campaign. If the people responsible for for these political campaigns were to be held to the same standard as a typical citizen, they all would be in court facing libel and slander charges.

It looks like Murdoch's minions, a.k.a. Fox News viewers, have gone out and done as instructed, and caucused for Santorum (recent NYT story "Taking to Twitter, Murdoch Signals Support for Santorum" http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/02/taking-to-twitter-murdoch-....

I have no intention of voting for any of these clowns, I'll take Obama any day.

But I do have to watch with concern to see the worst we could end up with, if Fox viewers continue voting the Murdoch party line (for those politicians in the revolving door between being paid Fox commentators, and Republican candidates), and if Citizens United unleashes enough anonymously financed trash to smear Obama the way it apparently successfully did Gingrich.

Wow - Mickeyrad - with whom I've had spirited disagreements with in the Disunion series about the Ciil War..

While not an actual Obama voter, I did want to see him win, and will definitely be registering Republican to vote for Ron Paul in the Oregon primary this year (and me a long time registered Green).

My great grandfather who had come alone at age 17 from Germany got his citizenship in Iowa in 1872 - I've got a copy of the papers somewhere and I'm pretty sure it was a republic he was signing up for, not an empire ore police state.

Do run run, Ron..

bluerepublican.org

My.my. There are more people living in my grand daughter's East Village neighorhood in Manhattan than 'Caucused' in Iowa, and yet we've been bombarded with this nonesense for weeks and weeks.  What is it with you guys?  Let's get this over with: Vote Obama.

Your results graphic has almost identical colors for Romney and Paul.
Wake up Art Department!
The remaining county on your map is Loisa County. It looks pretty rural. I'll bet the county goes for Santorum. If they don't, I'll eat my cotton candy hat hi hi.

Rick Santorum's strong showing in Iowa demonstrates how strongly Republicans want an alternative to Mitt Romney. On January 3, it was Mr. Santorum's time to surge, much as Ron Paul, Newt Gingrich and Michelle Bachman have surged in the past.

I don't blame Iowa Republicans for taking an 'anyone but Romney' approach, as Mr. Romney has yet to persuade most Americans of his sincerity. The only difficulty is that the alternatives to Mr. Romney do not inspire confidence either.

Over the last ten years .45% of the U.S. population engaged in combat, the lowest population percentage of any war. Only One percent served in the combat theatre. I think it should be noted that the definition of the word "OCCUPY"  is signifigantly different for the .45% as opposed to the 99% and its occupation. I would like to think it would be a bit more difficult to remove the .45% from a park.
I'm hoping that Huntsman stays in the hunt. He's the only  Republican a Democrat could imagine voting for without being stoned first.

24.6% will be the lowest winning total for any GOP Caucus winner. Meaning a lot of noses were held tonight. Each of these candidates has a fatal flaw - we're just seeing what happens when people are forced to select the least from a bunch of awful alternatives in a political version of a bizarre fraternity dare ritual.

If Newt makes good on his promise to spend his shiny new millions on destroying Mitt in the South for the duration of the contest, then I'm betting Santorum can emerge the eventual winner, especially if Perry is serious about dropping out and Bachmann might as well be doing so. Eventually, the non-Mitt voter will have too few alternatives to split their votes amongst - one consensus non-Mitt must eventually emerge and win this nomination. This "win" reveals the exact opposite for Mitt - he can never win this nomination since no more than a quarter of the nation's repubs will ever stomach the idea of voting for him. He's only been frontrunner for as long as he's had more than 3 opponents. That was always going to eventually change.
-Jeff

Santorum is not-the-other-guys.

That is not a basis on which to run in November.

Mr. Raghuvanshi, your comment is very perceptive. The problem is not just psychological, it is ingrained in deep religious mythology and spiritual tradition. The original Western paternal-god (actually a Middle-Eastern/Pharaoh-deity figure) is one who demanded bodily sacrifice from his "sons" and punished his "children" --begotten in "sin" -- for their disobedience with death, suffering and plague.

Then his more compassionate "son on earth" was brutally crucified for the "sins" of humanity, further convoluting a deeply dangerous mythology of abject self-loathing in the face of a violent and judging "god." Then, a subsequent iteration dictated that those who did not adhere to this mythology be murdered.

Oh, and by the way, this mythology dictates that the earth and all its creatures are for man's control and use, his dominion, as only man possesses a "soul."

This blood-soaked primitivism is the dominant mythology on the planet today. It's no wonder we're in such a mess.

Namaste. Your insight is provocative. How can we develop a global culture that allows for and encourages the full development of human personality and potential, when each sub-culture resists being absorbed and thereby eliminated? If we cannot find an answer to this question I fear human civilization has no where to go but back. Perhaps we really haven't come that far.

Western civilization is based on fear,so this natural struggle between Father and son.Western civilization blindly believed giving birth to son is misdeed is sin, on the contrary  Hindu civilization blindly believed give birth to son is overcome the  fear of  hell.Western civilization  treated child very harshly, disciplined  him strictly  so he revolt against this tyranny in  early younger age.In Hindu society  child reared pampering,over founding that   why Hindu youngster protested with father figure childishly.Oedipus Rex complex is very deeply inserted in psyche of western culture.on the contrary mother fixation is very deeply inserted in Hindu civilization. In my opinion greatest  question is how to change psyche of different   civilization so we can bring peace in the world?

Leon Panetta has the awesome task of reducing the Pentagon's budget.  Senator Tom Coburn's suggestion to reduce our overseas forces by 1/3 over 10 years is a good one.  But the Congress must do more to reduce expenditures across the board.  We must maintain a strong military nucleus at home.  This is essential to reinforce our commitment to our allies  in formulating prudent foreign policy.  Also, we must compete with China's strengthening of its economic, military and naval components.  Prior fo World War II  FDR and Winston Churchill forged an alliance of our people who sacrificed much in order to prevail over totalitarian tyranny. With proper leadership we can overcome  our current problems.

Romney's goal is to knock out Newt.  he didn't do it and won't do it regardless of outcome in New Hampshire.  Newt's firewall is South Carolina.  Santorum is just a distraction at the moment and Ron Paul will be a dog at Romney's ankle who may occasionally go deeper than a flesh wound.  Newt is still his problem.
Six candidates, six losers.
You guys see the pics of santorum in the results room with all those people and laptops around him on screen? Could we investigate this alittle moar?

Romney's won. He goes on from here to a 20 point lead in NH.  And the only other people who will vote for Santorum are other religious zealots -- a decisive force in the small number of Iowa GOP who go to such things, but a minority elsewhere. He won't even do that well in So. Carolina -- he's Catholic, where that's as weird as Mormon.

Yes, all he needs is one of these:
http://pilates.about.com/od/technique/ss/human-spine-anatomy_3.htm

'Would you ever in a million years move to Iowa?'

I note you are from Massachusetts. Have you ever been to Iowa? Nice place, in a lot of ways.

Would you buy clothes on the advice of Iowans? Would you follow their diets, watch their favorite TV shows? Would you ever in a million years move to Iowa?

Then why in god's name does anyone care what their party hacks have to say about presidential candidates?

Get on a ballot, run for six months maximum, and let the entire country vote. This elaborate rear-end-kissing to the two-party system is a pointless waste of national time.

@Terry:

It is disgraceful that Obama signed the NDAA, opening the door wide for transforming the USA into a 1970's Argentina.

The NDAA has been so under-reported that vast swaths of the American public have no idea that they are now living, officially, in a police state.

This is Obama's doing, and frankly I don't care what else he has done.

Flushing the Bill of Rights down the toilet means we have no one representing us now, certainly no Republican and no Democrat.

As I predicted he would be in a comment on Nate Silver's pre-caucus article Monday, Romney is the big loser tonight.  For months he has been unable to crack 25% in the national polls, and after finally admitting he was in Iowa to win, with big money pouring into the state from his SuperPAC, he polled, guess what, a hair under 25%, not even good for first place (with 97% of the vote counted).  Romney's BMW bogged down in a muddy Iowa cornfield, and Santorum's pick-up truck went past him.
Santorum's timing was perfect: Rise in the polls just before the election, so that attack ads cannot harm you. That'll change.

The NY Times just reported that Rick "Oops-Oops-Oops-Oops-Oops-Oops-Oops" Perry is heading back to Texas to assess his campaign's future.

My question: What took him so long?

Future no. Failure yes.

Just listened to Michele Bachmann.  If she means what she says, we should have nightmares tonight.  A woman who is responsible for 30  children does not want some kind of universal medical insurance for all children?.  She no one idea or her own. it is the same thoughtless tee-party mantra that is based on unabashed hatred to Obama. One senses a racist undertone in her she knows it.  This is why she invokes the "supporting Israel" mantra.
and illegal too boot
